citation.article-title: Bacteroides pyogenes sp. nov., Bacteroides suis sp. nov., and Bacteroides helcogenes sp. nov., new species from absesses and feces of pigs

p.s: Description of Bacteroides helcogenes sp. nov.
Bacteroides helcogenes (hel.co.ge'nes. Gr. n. helkos abscess; Gr. v. gennaio produce; M.L. adj. helcogenes abscess-producing)
Obligately anaerobic, Gram-negative, non-motile, non-pigmenting, non-spore rods.
Gram stains of single colonies from agar plates show predominantly short, Gram-negative rods, single or in pairs (0.5-0.6 μm by0.8-4.0 μm).
After 2 days incubation, surface colonies are 1.0-2.0 mm in diameter, circular with an entire edge, convex, translucent to opaque grey to grey-white, shiny, and smooth.
No growth on blood agar plates incubated in a candle-extinction jar or in an aerobic atmosphere.
After 1 day incubation, the pH in media containing a fermentable carbohydrate decreases to about 5.0.
Most strains do not grow in PYFG broth containing 20% bile.
Xylose, glucose, mannose, fructose, galactose, sucrose, maltose, lactose, cellubiose, melibiose, raffinose, starch, glycogen, salicin, amygdalin and xylan are fermented.
Arabinose, treahlose melezitose, glycerol, inulin, mannitol, sorbitol, inositol, adonitol, erythritol ad gum arabic are not fermented.
Indole is not produced; nitrate is not reduced.
Acetic and succinct acids and very small amounts of isobutyric and propionic acids are produced in PYFG broth.
All strains are susceptible to penicillin (10 μg/ml) and cepharothin (10 μm/ml).
The type strain is DSM 20613 (= P 36-108) isolated from abscess in pig.
